_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Center Point Terminal Company, LLC -

NORTH TERMINAL

3101 Talleyrand Avenue

Jacksonville, FL  32206



The Center Point Terminal Company - North Terminal stores and transfers LPG gases in regulated quantities. The regulated RMP substance handled at this facility is butane. Using the Risk Management Program Guidance Table 2 conversion guidance, approximately 1,440,000 pounds of product has been calculated as the maximum inventory of butane.  For this location, butane is received via tank truck into twelve (12) 30,000 gallon butane tanks (horizontal units).  The facility also has other tanks (vertical) on site (23 ambient pressure petroleum liquids (diesel and gasoline)).  On occasion, some butane may be injected into one or more ambient pressure gasoline tanks on site as a RVP enhancer.



Given the flammable nature of butane and other liquids on site, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling butane to prevent unnecessary human exposure at the site, and to reduce the threat to nearby members of the community. In this regard, safety at the company's facility depends upon the manner in which butane is handled as well as ensuring safety device integrity is incorporated into the design of the butane tanks and their ancillary equipment. Furthermore, comprehensive training received by site employees upon hiring adds to the inherent safety at the facility.



The OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) 29 CFR 1910.119 and EPA Risk Management Plan (RMP) Standards 40 CFR 68 / EPA CDX/FACILITY ID #100000230715 were developed by SCS Engineers in October 2015. In addition to the presence of appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of butane, if a release were to occur, the company operates in compliance with NFPA Code 30 (Fire Code for tank farms) and NFPA-58 (LPG gas code) in liaison with the Duval County Fire Department which helps to provide trained emergency response personnel that are knowledgeable on how to control and mitigate a release.

The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled

As stated above, the site receives, stores, and transfers butane which are blended with gasoline for octane enhancement. Butane arrives at the site via tank truck and is stored in twelve (12) 30,000 gallon storage tanks. 



The worst case release was developed using RMPComp software. In this regard, the following paragraphs provide details of the chosen scenario:

The worst case release scenario submitted for butane involves a catastrophic release from butane storage resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. The scenario involves the release of 1,440,000 lb. of butane. It is assumed that the entire quantity is released as a vapor that finds an ignition source. Assuming a wind speed of 1.5 meters/second and an air temperature of 77 F, the maximum distance of 0.9 miles was obtained corresponding to a flammable endpoint of 1 psi overpressure.

An alternative butane release scenario resulting in a Vapor Cloud Fire involves a release from a six inch hole in the liquid space of a tank. In this scenario, 869 lb. of butane is released in 10 minutes with a tank pressure of 100 psi. The release is controlled by active mitigation measures that include positive shutoff valves, excess flow valves, back flow check valves, and an emergency shutoff valve with mechanical, thermal, and remote capability. Under neutral weather conditions, the maximum distance to the flammable endpoint of lower flammability limit is less than 0.1 miles.



The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The facility has taken the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention risk management requirements set out under 40 CFR 68 of the EPA. This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with NFPA Code 30 and NFPA-58 and other applicable design codes in effect at the time of installation.



The following briefly describe the release prevention program that is in place at t

he company's site:

Safety Information

Center Point maintains a detailed record of written safety information, which describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with the aspects of the company's bulk liquid terminal. 



Hazard Review

A process hazard analysis was performed and is reviewed every three years. The reviews or periodic audits focus with extensive knowledge of facility operations and are revalidated on operating procedures, equipment functions and handling practices to identify possible hazards including employee participation, contractor safety, hot work permitting, and management of change. The audits are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel regular interval of three years per 40 CFR 68. Findings related to the hazard reviews are addressed in a safe and timely manner.



Operating Procedures

For the purposes of safely conducting activities within the company's covered operations, the site maintains written operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved with the operations. 



Training

Center Point has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees that are operating processes are completely competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes. New employees receive basic training in process operations followed by on-the-job supervision for three months or until they are deemed competent to work independently. Refresher training is provided on a continuing basis by experienced company personnel. 



Maintenance

Center Point carries out highly documented maintenance checks on butane and propane equipment to ensure proper functioning. Maintenance activities are carried out by qualified contractors cer

tified for such work. Furthermore, facility personnel as well as contractors are offered the specialized training that may be needed. Equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner. 



Compliance Audits

As stated, Center Point conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rules that are implemented. These audits are carried out at least every 3 years and corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner. Incident Investigation Center Point promptly investigates incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in, a catastrophic release of butane. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as corrective actions to prevent the release from recurring. Reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.

The Center Point has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years. Due to the company's stringent release prevention policies, there has been no accidental release during this period.



A written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of butane is maintained on site. The plan includes emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas. The company's facility's emergency response plan is based in large party upon the Oil Pollution Act of 1990 (OPA '90). To ensure proper functioning, the company's emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced. In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect pertinent changes taking place within CPTC's processes that would require a modified emergency response. The local Fire Department is the Local Emergency Responder with which the company's emergency plan has been coordinated and verified.
